executor.hint: Whether the creature that executes the ability will be associated with this condition.
executor.label: Associate Executor

relation.hint: What the relationship between the effect and condition is.

target.hint: Whether to open a dialog to select tokens that will be associated with this condition.
target.label: Select Associations

common.hint: Simple one-off effects that don't require customization.
common.label: Impacts

duration.hint: A formula that evaluates to a number of the specified unit.
duration.label: Formula

mode.hint: The arithmetic operation to apply to this effect's duration.
mode.label: Mode

hacks.hint: The types of hack damage that this can apply.

reverse.hint: Remove hacks instead of adding them.
reverse.label: Reverse

consumeStatDice.hint: Check this if hit dice should be consumed on use.
consumeStatDice.label: Consume Hit Dice

forHarm.hint: Check this if the healing should be done for damage.
forHarm.label: For Damage

noStatDice.hint: Whether this only displays the option to heal hacks.
noStatDice.label: No Stat Dice

title.hint: Text to display on the button. Leave blank for default text.
title.label: Label

pseudoHook.hint: The hook that executes this macro when fired.
pseudoHook.label: Hook

relation.hint: Whether this macro can be run as a button from the chat message or hooks into other behavior.

hex.hint: Whether this is a hexproof roll.

consumeStatDice.hint: Check this if mana dice should be consumed on use.
consumeStatDice.label: Consume Mana Dice

forHarm.hint: Check this if the revitalizing should be done for drain.
forHarm.label: For Drain

formula.hint: The formula to use for the roll.
formula.label: Formula

merge.hint: Whether to merge this roll with other valid rolls of the same type that have merging enabled.
merge.label: Merge

consumeStatDice.hint: Whether this consumes stat dice by default.
consumeStatDice.label: Consume Stat Dice

forHarm.hint: Whether this rolls dice for harm by default.
forHarm.label: For Harm

relation.hint: Apply, remove, toggle, or include the condition as part of the ability's effect.

amount.hint: A numerical amount of the effect to take. Leave blank to have it be the result of the roll.
amount.label: Amount

bonus.hint: Formula that defines a bonus that gets added to the roll. Can be negative.
bonus.label: Bonus

threshold.hint: Formula that defines the DC for this roll. Can be left blank.
threshold.label: Threshold

abilityNames.hint: Abilities that this can directly cause the execution of.
abilityNames.label: Abilities

Errors.noAddPath: No path specified for addChange action
Errors.noDeleteArray: No changes array found at path: {path}
Errors.noDeletePath: No path specified for deleteChange action

base.hint: Base changes are the first ones applied. They take effect right after base data for documents have been set up and before any derived values have been determined.
base.label: Base

derivation.hint: Derivation changes apply once derived data has been calculated. This should only be used for effects where the changes themselves rely on data that's been derived.
derivation.label: Derivation

final.hint: These are the last changes that are applied. There is very minimal document data prep that occurs after these changes, so they should only be used for instances where nothing passively relies on them.
final.label: Final

fluency.hint: Fluency changes apply immediately after proficiency ones. This should be used exclusively for effects that make other documents fluent.
fluency.label: Fluency

normal.hint: Normal changes are the last ones applied before derived values are determined. This is the default time that changes are applied and should be used unless there is a specific reason to apply at some other time.
normal.label: Normal

proficiency.hint: Proficiency changes apply immediately after base ones. This should be used exclusively for effects that make other documents proficient.
proficiency.label: Proficiency

ApplyEffect.cantSustain: Could not attach effect to the one that's sustaining it.
ApplyEffect.label: Apply Effect

StandardDamage.noDefaultWeapon: {name} doesn't have a default attack weapon.

Classes.archer: As precise and accurate as a well-crafted arrow, archers don't mess around. They prefer to keep their distance, as that is where they are the most effective, never letting anyone get too close to them. Archers are direct and focused and thus make the best guards. Ever vigilant, archers are always looking ahead as, if taken by surprise, they are easily killed. If you are playing an Archer be direct, and on target, sturdy and perhaps high strung, watchful of the future and of your back.
Classes.assassin: The shadiest of all the classes, Assassins see life as expendable and unimportant. Even their own life is trivial, someone will kill them sooner or later. That's life. Life is short and thus Assassins tend to get to the point quickly, literally. Some-what of a martial artist, there is something Zen about the Assassin's way, not unlike the @L[Class:Duelist]{Duelist} in that they have strong inner motivation, though care nothing for honor. Assassins try to increase hatred between people in the hopes of creating more job opportunities for themselves. If you're an Assassin, don't think twice about killing someone, care little for your own life and cut to the chase!
Classes.berserker: Wild and savage. They distrust magic of all kinds and put their faith in themselves before others. Always at the front of a battle, Berserkers love the sport of combat and don't like missile weapons. Not reliable as guards as they are too distracted and are rarely very intelligent. If you are a Berserker be larger than life, brash, not too bright and stupidly brave.
Classes.corsair: People of the sea, they are never very comfortable far from a large body of water. Corsairs are wanderers and like to be on the move. Corsairs tend to be humble in that they understand that nature is greater than they are and respect it for that. If you are an Corsair, crave water and sailing, go with the flow, keep on the move, and keep things ship shape.
Classes.duelist: Honor-bound and honest to the core, Duelists are often judges and referees for duels as well as devoted warriors. Duelists prize the honor of their family above any sort of personal gain and thus strive for excellence in everything that they do. A true Duelist wins the battle before it has begun. Strategy and personal perfection are the Duelist's way. If you are a Duelist, be calm, focused, well spoken and confident in yourself.
Classes.flameMage: Fierce and brazen, these mages are always at war. The arms dealers of the world, their magic is completely focused on destruction and thus they seek to create bigger and better ways to blow things up. Passionate, wild and a bit chaotic, these mages like the mountains and underground spaces. If you are playing a Flame Mage be hot tempered, war-like, ready for battle, and consuming everything.
Classes.knight: The true glory seekers, Knights are chivalrous to a point but have none of the @L[Class:Duelist]{Duelist's} respect for battles. Knights are the weapon masters, well-armored but relying on their swift, powerful attacks and powerful strength to destroy their enemy before they can counter-attack. Knights are the real behemoths of the battlefield, leading troops into the fray and slaughtering all they can. If you are a Knight, be looking for glory, looking for the next powerful weapon.
Classes.lifeMage: The true healers of the world, they are committed to sustaining all life. The truly altruistic characters, Life Mages are known to enter battles on neither side, healing anyone and everyone who they can. Obsessed with keeping people alive and conquering death, Life Mages are not as righteous as the Paladin but much more humble and kind. Shying away from combat, they prefer to stand behind the troops, healing when needed. If you are playing a Life Mage be helpful, kind and loving, protective but committed to saving lives and fighting death.
Classes.natureMage: The enchanter of the woods, these wandering spell casters resemble Rangers in their wanderlust. More comfortable with animals than people, Nature Mages are always heading to the woods and keeping to themselves. Ever in defense of the land, Nature Mages are like environmentalists. Nature Mages are in tune with the world at all times. If you are playing a Nature Mage be reclusive, avoiding people if you can, happy in nature and eager to leave any civilization.
Classes.necromancer: The true dealer of death, Necromancers are most at home in the cemetery digging up future minions. Shunned by most of society, these dark mages are not necessarily evil, they simply see death as full of potential energy while others see it as the end of life. Necromancers fear nothing, as they are always facing death. If you are playing a Necromancer be unafraid, kill without remorse and be interested in dead bodies, close to death yourself, almost in another world.
Classes.paladin: The least martial of the warriors, their outlook on life is that of the combat medic, focusing on keeping others alive on the front lines. Paladins are often leaders, as their charismatic charm draws followers to them and everyone likes to have a healer on their side. Paladins see themselves as somewhat better than most others as they have magical powers that other warriors lack. Paladins usually have a strong guiding force in their life to help those in need and do what is right. If you are a Paladin be righteous, concerned for others, and take charge.
Classes.ranger: The true wanderer, they are a bit like @L[Class:Corsair]{Corsairs} of the land. Always on the move and scouting about, rangers never like to have much responsibility if they can help it and prefer to be on their own. Gritty and worn like old leather, these characters are unflinching and realistic at all times. If you are playing a Ranger, keep watch, seek solitude, long for the woods and be introspective.
Classes.stormMage: The true wonder seeker, these mages are the philosophers of the world, always seeking out more knowledge and more wisdom. The Storm Mage is a logician, a tactical intellectual who prefers to neutralize opponents rather than destroy them. Often cold, the Storm Mage is also tumultuous and crafty. If you are playing a Storm Mage, be curious, hungry for information, always in the clouds, tricky and clever, eluding rather than confronting.
Classes.thief: Almost as shady as the @L[Class:Assassin]{Assassin}, a Thief is a bit more socially oriented and has a much greater care for her own life. Thieves are the flip side of the @L[Class:Duelist]{Duelist} and tend to follow laws and tell the truth only if it serves their purpose. Always trying to make a profit, thieves are the businessmen of the world and will cheat you without blinking an eyelash, that is their job. If you are playing a thief, lie and make up stories, be ever watchful for a chance to search or loot and look for the profit angle, never doing anything for free.
Classes.veteran: Jaded and tough, these warriors act as if they have seen it all. Obviously they are not all seasoned warriors, but the training of a Veteran involves a great deal of time in battle, so even a first rank Veteran has seen more action than other first rank warriors. The strategy of the Veteran is to be an immovable wall, and hold the line. Veterans rely on defense in battle, always working to better ensure their protection, which is why they survive to be veterans. If you are a Veteran be jaded, unimpressed, hard, and pessimistic.

Conditions.allured:
A creature that is allured to another creature will do whatever they tell them to. They are totally loyal to that other creature and also @L[Condition:Bound]{bound} to them. This is a @L[Category:Control effects]{control effect}, but it is not forcing actions directly. Rather, an allured creature wants to take action, is does so of their own volition. In a "regular" @L[Condition:Bound]{binding}, the creature is aware they are being @L[Category:Control effects]{controlled} and can attempt to thwart the confines of their tether. But an allured creature is not aware of the effect that's been placed on them. It is more akin to being insane, blurring reality and shaping it to what they believe to be true.

This rare and dangerous type of @L[Category:Control effects]{control} is usually employed by @L[Creature:Nymph]{nymphs}, @L[Category:Vampires]{vampires}, and other manipulative and generally evil creatures.
Conditions.anosmatic: If you are anosmatic then you have no sense of smell and cannot use any @L[Category:Abilities]{abilities} that would require one.
Conditions.asleep: A creature that's asleep is unconscious, but not necessarily at 0 or fewer @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{HP}. Unless otherwise specified, a creature that's asleep will @L[Keyword:Awaken]{awaken} if they take any damage (that doesn't reduce them to 0 or fewer @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{HP}) or if they are within range of something @L[Category:Loud effects]{loud}. If an effect specifies a range it can be heard at, it is assumed that half that range is the range it can wake sleeping creatures at.
Conditions.blind: If you are blind, then you cannot see anything and any @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attack} you make against another creature is done with @L[Core:Disadvantage]{disadvantage}.
Conditions.bound: If you are bound to another group, concept, or being, you cannot intentionally let them come to harm through action or inaction. This is a @L[Category:Control effects]{control effect}.
Conditions.burned: A burned creature is @L[Keyword:Incapable]{incapable} of @L[Core:Healing]{healing} itself with @L[Category:Regeneration effects]{regeneration effects}.
Conditions.charmed: A creature that is charmed has their allegiances switched. They will fight their former allies and defend their former foes. This does not change the alignment of the creature, only their loyalties. A charmed creature is visibly so, they have a glazed and bloodshot look in their eyes.
Conditions.conscious: A creature that's conscious is aware of its surroundings and can respond to stimuli. It can perceive its environment, process information, and act upon it. A conscious creature can also communicate, make decisions, and exhibit complex behaviors. This is the default state for most creatures. Any type of creature, including @L[Category:Undead creatures]{undead} and @L[Category:Construct creatures]{constructs} is able to be conscious.
Conditions.criticallyWounded: Creatures become critically wounded when they are 1 @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{HP} or @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{MP} above half their maximum @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{HP} or @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{MP} below zero but also have at least zero @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{HP} or @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{MP} respectively. This is 1 @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{HP} or @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{MP} above the threshold for being dead. A creature that's critically wounded cannot be @L[Keyword:Awaken]{awakened}.
Conditions.dead:
Creatures become dead if they are half their maximum @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{HP} or @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{MP} below zero @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{HP} or @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{MP} respectively. They cannot have their @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{HP} or @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{MP} reduced below this value. If a creature is @L[Condition:Down]{down} and at negative @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{HP} for more than 10 minutes, they die.

When a creature dies and is @L[Category:Revival effects]{revived}, they release control over anything that is no longer on their person, freeing up the corresponding @L[Core:Presence]{presence} in the process. This includes @L[Category:Equipment]{equipment} that is no longer equipped, mounts that no longer with them, and so on. They also must pull from the @L[Core:Death Bag]{death bag}.
Conditions.deaf: If you are deaf then you have no sense of hearing and cannot use any @L[Category:Abilities]{abilities} that would require one.
Conditions.defyingDeath:
If you are defying death, make an @L[Core:Presence]{UNP} @L[Core:Feat Interaction]{feat save} every time you would take @L[Core:Damage]{damage}. The DC of this save is equal to 6 plus the number of damage dice that would be dealt. If you succeed, you take no @L[Core:Damage]{damage} from that source. If you fail, you @L[Condition:Dead]{die}.

While defying death, you also @L[Keyword:Resistance]{resist} @L[Condition:Dead]{death} and @L[Condition:Unconscious]{unconsciousness}.
Conditions.disguised: A creature that's disguised is not @L[Condition:Transformed]{transformed}, but still appears differently than their natural form. Any creature can detect if someone is disguised using @L[Ability:Check Disguise]{Check Disguise}.
Conditions.down: A creature is down if it is @L[Condition:Unconscious]{unconscious} or @L[Condition:Dead]{dead}. The act of going from @L[Condition:Up]{up} to down is called "dropping". If a creature is down and at negative @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{HP} for more than 10 minutes, they @L[Condition:Dead]{die}.
Conditions.dueling:
Creatures that are dueling each other are @L[Category:Spiritual effects]{spiritually} linked to each other in a state that's slightly out of phase with everyone else. This doesn't have any inherent mechanical effects in and of itself, but it implies a structure for how those @L[Category:Creatures]{creatures} interact with each other and the world around them that may be interacted with by @L[Category:Duel modifying effects]{duel modifying effects} or other @L[Category:Abilities]{abilities}. The term "in a duel" is often used to refer to a creature that is dueling. This does not mean that the "duel" must have been started by @L[Ability:Duel]{Duel}.

If a creature that is dueling becomes incapacitated, then they are considered to have "lost" the duel. If a dueling creature incapacitates themselves, they are considered to have "forfeited" the duel which in turn also makes them count as "losing". If a dueling creature @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacks} a creature that they are not dueling, that is also considered to be "forfeiting". If a creature is ever the only one remaining in a given duel, the duel ends and they are considered to have "won" the duel.

Duels typically have a "range" of 30 feet. This means that if any creature that is dueling @L[Ability:Move]{Moves} more than 30 feet away from any other creature that they are dueling with, they are considered to have "forfeited" the duel.

The dueling state is not visible in the Material Realm, but there is a very slight tether that can be seen in the @L[Condition:Ethereal]{Ethereal Realm}. There are no restrictions on what realm a duel can take place in, but all participants must be within the same realm. Any participant that leaves that realm is considered to have gone out of range and therefore "lost the duel".
Conditions.encumbered:
An encumbered creature can be either lightly encumbered or heavily encumbered. The consequences are as follows.

Lightly Encumbered
The creature's @L[Core:Movement Speed]{movement speed} is reduced by 10.
Heavily Encumbered
The creature is @L[Condition:Slowed]{slowed}. The creature also has @L[Core:Disadvantage]{disadvantage} on @L[Core:Attack Interaction]{attacks} and @L[Core:Movement]{MOV} @L[Core:Feat Interaction]{feat saves}.
Conditions.ethereal:
If a creature is ethereal, it is in the Ethereal Realm. This is the domain of spirits and does not take kindly to those with a physical form. Ethereal beings cannot typically be interacted with nor sensed by material (non-ethereal) ones. The main exception is that if an ethereal being passes within 5 feet of a material one, the material creature feels a strange unnatural chill pass over them.

If a creature that's ethereal is not innately a spirit, then they still have a size and shape while ethereal, but it is blurry and transparent. They cannot pass through material (non-ethereal) walls or objects. However, they also cannot push, pull, grab, nor interact with material objects in any way. It is as though the ethereal creature has no material strength whatsoever.

If you go @L[Condition:Down]{down} while ethereal, you @L[Condition:Dead]{die}, become a @L[Condition:Wisping]{wisp} and your body dissipates. Any being that has a physical form and that isn't being kept ethereal by some effect will manifest back into the Material Realm at dawn. They remember what they experienced while ethereal, but the details and order of events is a little jumbled and hazy.

There is a slight whooshing sound like a gust of wind whenever a creature enters or exits the Ethereal Realm.
Conditions.frenzied: While frenzied, you will not leave combat willingly and are @L[Keyword:Inept]{inept} at not killing anyone who opposes you. This includes anyone who tries to stop you through actions or words. You are also @L[Keyword:Resistant]{resistant} to being @L[Condition:Frightened]{frightened}.
Conditions.frightened: A frightened creature cannot make @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacks} against nor intentionally @L[Ability:Move]{get closer to} the source of their fear.
Conditions.frozen: A creature with this condition cannot use any @L[Category:Abilities]{abilities} or be affected by anything until this condition is cleared. They have no perception of the world around them or the passage of time at all. Any other ongoing @L[Category:Conditions]{conditions} or other ongoing effects are paused while this condition is in place.
Conditions.goaded: A creature that's goaded has @L[Core:Disadvantage]{disadvantage} on @L[Core:Attack Interaction]{attacks} against creatures other than ones that caused it to be goaded.
Conditions.grounded: If a creature is grounded then their flying, climbing, and leaping (both vertical and horizontal) @L[Core:Movement Speed]{speed adjustments} are set to "none".
Conditions.hacked:
A creature that's hacked is one suffering from @L[Damage:Hack]{hack damage}. Hack damage does not reduce @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{HP}. Instead, it applies different @L[Category:Conditions]{conditions} or effects to creatures depending on the part of their body being hacked. Hack damage will always have some body part specified.

Arm Hacks
1st Arm Hack: @L[Category:Attack abilities]{Attacks} you make with handheld @L[Category:Item delivery abilities]{items}, @L[Category:Missile delivery abilities]{missiles}, or your @L[Category:Hand delivery abilities]{hands} are done with @L[Core:Disadvantage]{disadvantage}. And you cannot make any @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacks} requiring two hands (such as those with @L[Property:Two-Handed]{two-handed} @L[Category:Weapons]{weapons}). You also cannot execute @L[Category:Somatic component abilities]{somatic abilities} unless both your hands are free.
2nd Arm Hack: You now cannot @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attack}, @L[Category:Block abilities]{block}, nor use any other @L[Category:Abilities]{abilities} with handheld @L[Category:Item delivery abilities]{items}, @L[Category:Missile delivery abilities]{missiles}, or your @L[Category:Hand delivery abilities]{hands} at all. You also cannot execute @L[Category:Somatic component abilities]{somatic abilities} at all.
Leg Hacks
1st Leg Hack: You are @L[Condition:Slowed]{slowed} and @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacks} you make with your @L[Equipment:Foot]{feet} are done with @L[Core:Disadvantage]{disadvantage}.
2nd Leg Hack: You are @L[Condition:Immobilized]{immobilized} and cannot make @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacks} with your @L[Equipment:Foot]{feet}.
Vitals Hacks
The effects of Vitals Hacks have even more granularity. Vitals Hacks will always have a more specific body part specified and apply effects accordingly.
Vitals Ear Hack: You are @L[Condition:Deaf]{deaf}.
Vitals Eye Hack: You are @L[Condition:Blind]{blind}.
Vitals Nose Hack: You are @L[Condition:Anosmatic]{anosmatic}.
Vitals Mouth Hack: You are @L[Condition:Mute]{mute} and cannot make @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacks} with your @L[Category:Equipment]{mouth}.
Body Hacks
You are @L[Condition:Immobile]{immobile}.

Despite not reducing @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{HP}, hack damage can be @L[Core:Healing]{healed}. @L[Core:Healing]{Healing} hack damage does not typically consume @L[Core:Hit Dice]{hit dice}. However, one @L[Core:Hit Dice]{hit die} worth of @L[Core:Healing]{healing} only mends one Hack. Each type of Vitals Hack must be @L[Core:Healing]{healed} independently. Arms and legs must receive an amount of @L[Core:Healing]{healing} equal to the amount of Hacks they've taken in order to be fully @L[Core:Healing]{healed}.
Conditions.hidden:
When you are hidden, you cannot be seen. This condition is always associated with some hidden DC it takes to see you. Unless otherwise noted, it's your @L[Core:Passive Attributes]{passive} @L[Core:Sneak]{sneak} (10 + 2 × @L[Core:Sneak]{SNK}). Other creatures will only be able to see you (or know that you're there) if they use @L[Ability:Perceive]{some relevant ability} that lets them do so, if their @L[Core:Passive Attributes]{passive} @L[Core:Perception]{perception} (10 + 2 × @L[Core:Perception]{PER}) is greater than your hidden DC, or if enabled to by some other effect. In most cases, a creature trying to see you will have some check which must pass your hidden DC.

While hidden, if someone knows where you are but is unable to see you, any @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacks} they make against you are done with @L[Core:Disadvantage]{disadvantage}. Similarly, any @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacks} you make against someone that can't see you are done with @L[Core:Advantage]{advantage}. @L[Category:Attack abilities]{Attacking} causes you to no longer be hidden.

While hidden, you must not @L[Ability:Move]{Move} faster than your @L[Core:Movement Speed]{hidden speed}. Any other @L[Category:Movement effects]{movement effects} require a DC 15 @L[Core:SNK]{SNK} @L[Core:Feat Interaction]{feat save} to remain hidden.
Conditions.hollied: A creature with this condition @L[Keyword:Resistance]{resists} all @L[Category:Reanimation effects]{reanimation effects}.
Conditions.immobilized: If a creature is immobilized then all their @L[Core:Movement Speed]{movement speed adjustments} are set to "none" and they are @L[Keyword:Incapable]{incapable} of using @L[Category:Movement effects]{movement effects} or otherwise @L[Ability:Move]{moving} of their own volition. They also automatically fail all @L[Category:MOV save abilities]{MOV saves}.
Conditions.invisible: An invisible creature cannot be seen. It is as though the creature is @L[Condition:Hidden]{hidden}, but movement does not typically break invisibility and cannot be seen with @L[Ability:Perceive]{Perceive}.
Conditions.lighted: A lighted creature cannot make @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacks} against at least 1 other creature, as specified by the source of the effect.
Conditions.meleeDodging: Melee attacks have @L[Core:Disadvantage]{disadvantage} against a creature that is melee dodging.
Conditions.missileDodging: Ranged attacks have @L[Core:Disadvantage]{disadvantage} against a creature that is missile dodging.
Conditions.mute: If you are Mute then you cannot speak nor use any @L[Category:Verbal component abilities]{abilities that require verbal components}.
Conditions.odorless: An odorless creature cannot be detected by scent.
Conditions.paralyzed: A creature that is paralyzed is completely physically inert. They are @L[Condition:Immobilized]{immobilized}, cannot use any @L[Category:Active abilities]{active}, @L[Category:Reactive abilities]{reactive}, or @L[Category:Slow abilities]{slow abilities}, and they automatically fail all @L[Category:STR save abilities]{STR save abilities}.
Conditions.poisoned: A creature that is poisoned has a recurring @L[Category:Effects]{effect} that applies to them at the start of their turn. By default, the @L[Category:Effects]{effect} is 1d6 @L[Damage:Toxic]{toxic damage}. The effect could be something else specified in the source of the poisoned condition.
Conditions.prone: A creature that's prone may only @L[Ability:Move]{Move} by @L[Core:Movement Speed]{crawling}, unless it @L[Core:Special Movements]{stands up} and thereby stops being prone. A prone creature also has @L[Core:Disadvantage]{disadvantage} with all @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacks} and @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacks} made against them from within 5 feet of them have @L[Core:Advantage]{advantage}. Otherwise, an @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attack} made against a prone creature has @L[Core:Disadvantage]{disadvantage}.
Conditions.ruined: A ruined body is one that has been damaged beyond the point of normal @L[Core:Healing]{healing} or @L[Category:Revival effects]{reviving}. If a creature's body is ruined, then it must be reconstructed before the creature can be brought back from @L[Condition:Dead]{the dead}. This is most often done through @L[Ability:Summon the Dead]{Summon the Dead}.
Conditions.silenced: A creature that is Silenced is @L[Condition:Mute]{mute} and @L[Keyword:Incapable]{incapable} of non-@L[Category:Basic abilities]{basic} @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attack} and @L[Category:Feat abilities]{feat} @L[Category:Abilities]{abilities}.
Conditions.silent: A silent creature cannot be detected by sound.
Conditions.slowed: If a creature is slowed then all their @L[Core:Movement Speed]{movement speed adjustments} are lowered one step, all @L[Core:Special Movements]{special movements} they make cost twice as much movement, and they make @L[Category:MOV save abilities]{MOV saves} with @L[Core:Disadvantage]{disadvantage}.
Conditions.snared: If a creature is Snared then they are @L[Condition:Immobile]{immobile} and cannot be @L[Category:Movement effects]{moved} by themself nor by others. They also have @L[Core:Disadvantage]{disadvantage} on all @L[Category:MOV save abilities]{MOV saves}.
Conditions.suffocating: A creature that's suffocating must spend a @L[Core:Hit Dice]{hit die} at the start of each of their turns or they drop to 0 @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{HP}. If they have 0 or fewer @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{HP}, then they instead @L[Condition:Dead]{die}.
Conditions.terrored: A creature with this condition @L[Keyword:Resistance]{resists} all @L[Category:Healing effects]{Healing} and @L[Category:Revival effects]{Revival effects}.
Conditions.transformed:
If a creature is transformed then they are in a different form than their original form. Transformations can have different levels of strength.

Minor Transformation
A minor transformation is a transformation that is not very strong and is usually temporary. It can be reverted with a @L[Ability:Treeform Ball]{Treeform Ball}, a @L[Ability:Force Revert]{Force Revert}, or with a @L[Ability:Self Revert]{Self Revert} (DC 6 @L[Core:INT]{INT} @L[Core:Feat Interaction]{feat save}). Minor transformations do not change creatures' @L[Core:Intelligence]{INT} nor maximum @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{MP}. Minor transformations cannot be "layered". That is, if a creature is minorly transformed into one form, and then minorly transformed into another, reverting from the second form puts them back into their original state. They do not revert into the first form they transformed into. Creatures are not @L[Core:Proficiency Bonus]{proficient} in @L[Category:Abilities]{abilities} they gain from being minorly transformed.
Full Transformation
A full transformation is stronger than a minor transformation. It cannot be reverted with a @L[Ability:Treeform Ball]{Treeform Ball} or a @L[Ability:Force Revert]{Force Revert}. But it can be reverted with a @L[Ability:Self Revert]{Self Revert} (DC 12 @L[Core:INT]{INT} @L[Core:Feat Interaction]{feat save}). Full transformations change creatures' @L[Core:Intelligence]{INT} from that of their original form to the one they're transformed into at a rate of 1 per month. It takes the same amount of time to recover if reverted. A creature's maximum @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{MP} does not change as a result of a full transformation until their @L[Core:Intelligence]{INT} has fully changed. Similarly to minor transformations, full transforms can't be layered on top of each other. However, a fully transformed creature can then be minorly transformed. If that minor transformation is reverted, the creature then returns to their fully transformed state. Creatures are not @L[Core:Proficiency Bonus]{proficient} in @L[Category:Abilities]{abilities} they gain from being fully transformed.
Greater Transformation
A greater transformation is even stronger than a full transformation. It can be reverted with a @L[Ability:Self Revert]{Self Revert} (DC 18 @L[Core:INT]{INT} @L[Core:Feat Interaction]{feat save}). Greater transformations immediately change creature's @L[Core:Intelligence]{INT} and maximum @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{MP} to that of whatever they're transformed into. The original @L[Core:Intelligence]{INT} and maximum @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{MP} are instantly restored upon reverting from a greater transformation. As with minor and full transformations, greater transformations do not layer on top of each other. However, a full or minor transformation can be layered on top of a greater in the same way that a minor transformation can be layered on a full one.
Conditions.unconscious: A creature that's unconscious is incapacitated. They are @L[Condition:Down]{down}, but @L[Condition:Alive]{alive}. They have no awareness of their surroundings, and can't use any non-passive @L[Category:Abilities]{abilities}. They also automatically fail any @L[Category:Feat abilities]{feat saves}. A creature that's unconscious with 0 or greater @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{HP}, but not @L[Condition:Asleep]{asleep} will @L[Keyword:Awaken]{awaken} after 1 hour.
Conditions.wisping: When a creature is wisping, their spirit has separated from their body. They have the stats of a @L[Creature:Wisp]{wisp} and exist in a dreamlike state. They cannot interact with their surroundings and typically have no other items nor abilities. Wisps are always @L[Condition:Ethereal]{Ethereal}.

Keywords.adept: If you are adept at something, then doing it costs 1 less @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{MP} (with a minimum of 0).
Keywords.av0: If an @L[Core:Attack Interaction]{attack} is AV0, it has a +2 to hit. This doesn't stack. If an @L[Core:Attack Interaction]{attack} would be AV0 for multiple reasons, it still only has a +2 to hit.
Keywords.awaken: A being being awakened goes from @L[Condition:Unconscious]{unconscious} to @L[Condition:Conscious]{conscious}. This does not count as @L[Core:Healing]{healing} and does not necessarily restore any @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{HP} nor other @L[Category:Damage types]{types of damage}. If the creature being awakened had less than 1 @L[Core:HP]{HP}, they now have 1.
Keywords.bearing: If a creature is carrying some item on their person then they are considered to be bearing it and are referred to as the item's "bearer". This is the case regardless of how the creature carries the item or if they are @L[Keyword:Using]{using} it.
Keywords.blessing: A blessing is a @L[Category:Divinely powered abilities]{divine ability} or set of @L[Category:Divinely powered abilities]{abilities} that is either directly granted by a divine entity or @L[Category:Blessing granting abilities]{through some ability} (such as @L[Ability:Divine Gift]{Divine Gift} or @L[Ability:Blessing]{Blessing}) that connects to one. Not all @L[Category:Divinely powered abilities]{divinely powered abilities} count as blessings. It should be specifically noted when something is a blessing.
Keywords.boosted: When an @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attack} is boosted, one more of the largest damage die is added to the @L[Core:Damage]{damage roll}. If there's multiple damage dice of the same size that would tie for being the largest, combine all the different @L[Category:Damage types]{damage types} together in the damage die that is added.
Keywords.curse: A curse is a @L[Category:Flaw abilities]{flaw} that remains on a creature even if whatever gave the curse is no longer present. A creature can only have up to three curses on them. Once they have a fourth curse, the curses all blend together into more powerful curse as determined by the @L[Core:Game Master]{GM}.
Keywords.deboosted: When an @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attack} is deboosted, the largest damage die is removed from the @L[Core:Damage]{damage roll}. If there are multiple damage dice with different @L[Category:Damage types]{damage types}, a random one is removed.
Keywords.effective: An effective @L[Category:Abilities]{ability} is identical to the normal version of it, except it is not considered to be @L[Category:Standard abilities]{standard}, a @L[Category:Spells]{spell}, nor a @L[Category:Skills]{skill}. It is not associated with any @L[Category:Classes]{class} and does not have any of the @L[Core:Power Sources]{power sources} (nor power-associated @L[Category:Effects]{effect types}) of the base @L[Category:Abilities]{ability}. New @L[Core:Power Sources]{power sources} will be specified instead (such as "@L[Category:Divinely powered abilities]{Divine} Effective @L[Ability:Lightning Ray]{Lightning Ray}"). If no @L[Core:Power Sources]{power source} is specified, then the @L[Category:Abilities]{ability} is @L[Category:Martially powered abilities]{martial}. The @L[Category:Abilities]{ability} may also be specified to be a @L[Category:Spells]{spell}, @L[Category:Skills]{skill}, or anything else as appropriate.
Keywords.expertise: If you make a @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{check} with expertise then you do so with an additional +2 bonus. This is referred to as being an expert. This supersedes the bonus gained from being @L[Keyword:Talented]{talented} and does not stack with it. If a @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{check} would have expertise from multiple sources, then it still only gains the +2 bonus once. However, expert stacks with other bonuses, such as those granted by @L[Core:Proficiency Bonus]{proficiency} or @L[Core:Tradecraft Fluencies]{fluency}.
Keywords.gifted: If an @L[Category:Abilities]{ability} is gifted, it costs 1 additional @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{MP} per use. If it is @L[Category:Passive abilities]{passive}, then it takes a @L[Category:Single action abilities]{single action} to execute and has a duration of 1 minute.
Keywords.hexproof: If a creature is hexproof to something, then it is as though they are @L[Keyword:Resistance]{resistant} to it, except that they can choose whether or not they make a @L[Keyword:Resistance]{resistance save}.
Keywords.hexseal: If a creature is hexsealed to something, then it is as though they are @L[Keyword:Immunity]{immune} to it, except that they can choose whether or not they take it.
Keywords.illusionary:
If an effect is Illusionary, then its presence is merely a trick of the mind and it's not really there. Illusions can have different levels of strength.

Minor Illusion
A Minor Illusion is a purely sensory experience that can be seen, heard, or felt. It can not, however, be physically touched or interacted with. A Minor Illusion can be detected with @L[Ability:Detect Illusion]{Detect Illusion} or disbelieved with @L[Ability:Disbelieve]{Disbelieve} (DC 6 @L[Core:INT]{INT} @L[Core:Feat Interaction]{feat save}). If disbelieved, the creature disbelieving can choose to no longer perceive the illusion.
Full Illusion
A Full Illusion can be touched and interacted with, but it is still not real. Nevertheless, Full Illusions can be quite dangerous if they are not recognized as such and can still cause physical harm. A Full Illusion can be detected with @L[Ability:Detect Illusion]{Detect Illusion} or disbelieved with @L[Ability:Disbelieve]{Disbelieve} (DC 12 @L[Core:INT]{INT} @L[Core:Feat Interaction]{feat save}). If disbelieved, the creature still perceives the illusion, but is no longer affected by it.
Greater Illusion
A Greater Illusion is a powerful effect that can be touched and interacted with and that is very hard to overcome. A Greater Illusion can be detected with @L[Ability:Detect Illusion]{Detect Illusion} or disbelieved with @L[Ability:Disbelieve]{Disbelieve} (DC 18 @L[Core:INT]{INT} @L[Core:Feat Interaction]{feat save}). If disbelieved, the creature disbelieving it has only 5 seconds of respit where they are not affected by the illusion. After that, the illusion is back to full strength.

The @L[Core:GM]{GM} may choose to change the DC of the @L[Ability:Disbelieve]{Disbelieve} check based on the complexity or power of the illusion.
Keywords.immunity: If you are immune to something, it does not work against you at all. A @L[Keyword:Warded]{warded} @L[Core:Abilities]{ability} does not cut through immunities.
Keywords.improved: An Improved @L[Category:Abilities]{ability} is one that is identical to some other @L[Category:Abilities]{ability}, but that is better in some way. The Improved @L[Category:Abilities]{ability} still counts as the original @L[Category:Abilities]{ability} for all other purposes (being @L[Keyword:Incapable]{incapable} of it, making it @L[Keyword:Adept]{adept}, etc.).
Keywords.incapable: If a creature is Incapable of something, then they are not able to do it even if some effect would otherwise make them able to.
Keywords.inept: If a creature is inept at something, then doing it costs them 1 additional @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{MP}.
Keywords.innate: Some @L[Category:Creatures]{species} have innate ranks. These are similar to the ones earned by @L[Core:Leveling Up]{leveling up} except that they no not provide any @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{hit dice nor mana dice} and do not count towards learning @L[Category:Guildmaster abilities]{guildmaster abilities}. @L[Category:Creatures]{Creatures} are proficient in the @L[Category:Abilities]{abilities} provided by their innate ranks.
Keywords.invoke: If an @L[Category:Invoked component abilities]{ability} is invoked then it requires that the creature executing it be wielding a @L[Category:Magelore equipment]{magelore item} and that the @L[Category:Invoked component abilities]{ability} has @L[Category:Verbal component abilities]{verbal} and @L[Category:Somatic component abilities]{somatic} components.
Keywords.knockout: A @L[Category:Knockout effects]{knockout effect} cannot @L[Core:Damage]{damage} a creature to below 0 @L[Core:Hit Points and Mana Points]{HP}.
Keywords.limited: A limited @L[Category:Abilities]{ability} is one that is identical to some other @L[Category:Abilities]{ability}, but that is worse in some way. The limited @L[Category:Abilities]{ability} still counts as the original @L[Category:Abilities]{ability} for all other purposes (being @L[Keyword:Incapable]{incapable} of it, making it @L[Keyword:Adept]{adept}, etc.).
Keywords.mastery: If you make a @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{check} with mastery then you do so with an additional +3 bonus. This is referred to as being a master. This supersedes the bonus gained from being @L[Keyword:Talented]{talented} or an @L[Keyword:Expertise]{expert} and does not stack with it. If a @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{check} would have mastery from multiple sources, then it still only gains the +3 bonus once. However, master stacks with other bonuses, such as those granted by @L[Core:Proficiency Bonus]{proficiency} or @L[Core:Tradecraft Fluencies]{fluency}.
Keywords.resistance: When a creature would be affected by something they are resistant to, they make a resistance save. This is a DC 10 d20 roll that they add their @L[Core:Proficiency Bonus]{proficiency bonus} to if they are @L[Core:Proficiency Bonus]{proficient} in the @L[Core:Abilities]{ability} that grants them their resistance. On a success, the target is not affected by whatever was going to happen to them. On a fail, they are. Resistance saves cannot be failed automatically. Only one resistance save can be attempted per @L[Core:Interactions]{interaction}. A resistance cannot stop a @L[Keyword:Warded]{warded} @L[Core:Abilities]{ability}.
Keywords.talented: If you make a @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{check} with talent then you do so with an additional +1 bonus. This is referred to as being talented. If a @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{check} would have talent from multiple sources, then it still only gains the +1 bonus once. However, talented stacks with other bonuses, such as those granted by @L[Core:Proficiency Bonus]{proficiency} or @L[Core:Tradecraft Fluencies]{fluency}.
Keywords.unblockable: If an attack is unblockable ("UB"), it is @L[Keyword:AV0]{AV0} and cannot be @L[Core:Block Interaction]{blocked}.
Keywords.undead: There are several different levels of @L[Category:Undead creatures]{undead} that @L[Category:Creatures]{creatures} can be.
Keywords.using: If a creature is @L[Keyword:Bearing]{bearing} an item in the way it would be intended (wearing a ring on their finger, wielding a sword in their hand, and so on) or in some way that would be just as effective (using a sword in a prehensile tail instead of their hand), then they are considered to be "using" the item.
Keywords.visions:
Sometimes effects such as @L[Ability:Oracle]{Oracle} grant a creature some vision of the past, present, or future. These visions are not always clear nor truthful, but they can be used to gain insight into the world around you. Visions can come in many forms.

Minor Visions
A minor vision is a brief flash of insight, a momentary glimpse of something that has been, is, or will be. They may be an emotion, a cryptic phrase, a single blurry image, or other small sensation.
Full Visions
A full vision is a more complete experience, often involving multiple senses. You might see a scene play out in front of you, hear the sounds of a distant place, or hear a complete riddle in your mind. These visions are often more vivid and detailed than minor visions, but it is still possible to distinguish the from reality.
Greater Visions
A greater vision is a powerful experience, often involving multiple senses and a strong emotional component. These visions can be overwhelming, leaving you disoriented or confused and are often impossible to distinguish from reality. These could be a prophetic dream, a complete vision of a past event, or even a glimpse of the future.
Keywords.vulnerable: If a creature is vulnerable to someone or something, they cannot @L[Keyword:Resistance]{resist} that person or thing, their @L[Category:Abilities]{abilities}, @L[Core:Damage]{damage} they deal, or any other @L[Category:Effects]{effects} directly caused by them. This does not apply to indirect effects. For instance, if a creature were @L[Keyword:Resistance]{resistant} to @L[Core:Damage]{damage}, but vulnerable to another creature, they would not be able to @L[Keyword:Resistance]{resist} @L[Core:Damage]{damage} resulting from an @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attack} that creature made against them. However, they would @L[Keyword:Resistance]{resist} the @L[Core:Damage]{damage} dealt due to hitting the ground if that creature pushed them off a cliff.
Keywords.warded: A warded effect is one that cannot be @L[Keyword:Resistance]{resisted}. This applies to all @L[Keyword:Resistance]{resistances} in an @L[Core:Interactions]{interaction chain}.

Tradecrafts.artist: Artist @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to create and evaluate works of art.
Tradecrafts.blacksmith: Blacksmith @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to forge @L[Category:Armor]{armor}, @L[Category:Weapons]{weapons}, and other metal goods. It can also be used to understand the make and quality of metal @L[Category:Equipment]{items}.
Tradecrafts.builder: Builder @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to build and repair wooden or stone objects and structures. It can also be used to understand the make and quality of such objects and structures.
Tradecrafts.cartographer: Cartographer @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to navigate and read or make maps.
Tradecrafts.chef: Chef @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to cook, prepare, serve, and evaluate food.
Tradecrafts.courtier: Courtier @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to befriend, manipulate, and deceive, and adjust the attitudes of other cratures.
Tradecrafts.diplomat: Diplomat @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to understand the law and navigate the political landscape.
Tradecrafts.enforcer: Enforcer @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to intimidate others and appear authoritative.
Tradecrafts.farmer: Farmer @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to grow and tend crops or gardens to produce food. It can also be used to recognize edible plants.
Tradecrafts.gambler: Gambler @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to play games of skill or luck and assess the odds of things.
Tradecrafts.herbalist: Herbalist @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to gather herbs and prepare herbal remedies. It can also be used to apply basic medicine to other creatures.
Tradecrafts.historian: Historian @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to research and understand past events as well as the people, places, and items associated with them.
Tradecrafts.hunter: Hunter @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to trap or hunt animals for food and hides. It can also be used to know what parts of animals are useful for different purposes.
Tradecrafts.innkeeper: Innkeeper @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to find information about other people and hear or spread rumors.
Tradecrafts.investigator: Investigator @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to search areas for hidden objects. It can also be used to hide objects.
Tradecrafts.locksmith: Locksmith @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to assemble, pick, and evaluate locks.
Tradecrafts.mariner: Mariner @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to sail and understand @L[Category:Ship target abilities]{ships} and the sea. It can also be used to understand the workings of ships and how to repair them.
Tradecrafts.messenger: Messenger @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to recall words, phrases, and other information you have encountered previously.
Tradecrafts.metaphysicist: Metaphysicist @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to recognize and interpret arcane features of the world. Although this @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{tradecraft} may often come up, it is not standardly learnable.
Tradecrafts.miner: Miner @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to find your way in or out of caves and dungeons. It can also be used to understand the properties of minerals and ores.
Tradecrafts.peacekeeper: Peacekeeper @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to know if other creatures are attempting to lie or deceive you.
Tradecrafts.performer: Performer @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to impress, entertain, and distract other creatures. It can also be used to recognize or evaluate the quality of performances.
Tradecrafts.priest: Priest @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to tend shrines or temples and understand theology.
Tradecrafts.scribe: Scribe @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to speak, read, and write in Common or other languages.
Tradecrafts.tailor: Tailor @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to sew and repair clothing and other cloth @L[Category:Equipment]{items}. It can also be used to understand the make and quality of cloth @L[Category:Equipment]{items}.
Tradecrafts.tamer: Tamer @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to tame, calm, or rile up wild and domesticated animals. It can also be used to intuit an animal's intentions.
Tradecrafts.teacher: Teacher @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to train others and share your knowledge.
Tradecrafts.tinkerer: Tinkerer @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to comprehend and fiddle with machinery. Although this @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{tradecraft} may often come up, it is not standardly learnable.
Tradecrafts.tracker: Tracker @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to find your way in the wild and follow or evade others.
Tradecrafts.trader: Trader @L[Core:Tradecrafts]{checks} can be used to make deals with other creatures and find opportunities to trade that wouldn't otherwise be available.

WeaponFightingStyles.bluntForce: Weapons with this @L[Category:Weapon fighting styles]{fighting style} gain @L[Core:Style Bonus]{SB} when you're @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacking} with a @L[Category:Knockout effects]{knockout effect}.
WeaponFightingStyles.charging: Weapons with this @L[Category:Weapon fighting styles]{fighting style} gain @L[Core:Style Bonus]{SB} when you're @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacking} a creature you moved at least 5 feet towards this @L[Core:Turns]{turn}.
WeaponFightingStyles.gladiator: Weapons with this @L[Category:Weapon fighting styles]{fighting style} gain @L[Core:Style Bonus]{SB} when you're @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacking} a @L[Condition:Prone]{prone}, @L[Condition:Snared]{snared}, @L[Condition:Frightened]{frightened}, @L[Condition:Hacked]{hacked}, or @L[Condition:Goaded]{goaded} creature.
WeaponFightingStyles.greatKenjutsu: Weapons with this @L[Category:Weapon fighting styles]{fighting style} gain @L[Core:Style Bonus]{SB} when you're @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacking} a creature smaller than you on another creature's @L[Core:Turns]{turn}.
WeaponFightingStyles.greatSwordsman: Weapons with this @L[Category:Weapon fighting styles]{fighting style} gain @L[Core:Style Bonus]{SB} when you're @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacking} a creature smaller than you for the first time on your @L[Core:Turns]{turn}.
WeaponFightingStyles.javelinier: Weapons with this @L[Category:Weapon fighting styles]{fighting style} gain @L[Core:Style Bonus]{SB} when you're @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacking} with a @L[Property:Thrown]{thrown} @L[Core:Attack Interaction]{attack}.
WeaponFightingStyles.juttejutsu: Weapons with this @L[Category:Weapon fighting styles]{fighting style} gain @L[Core:Style Bonus]{SB} when you're @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacking} a creature you've @L[Category:Block abilities]{blocked} since the end of your last @L[Core:Turns]{turn}.
WeaponFightingStyles.kenjutsu: Weapons with this @L[Category:Weapon fighting styles]{fighting style} gain @L[Core:Style Bonus]{SB} when you're @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacking} on another creature's @L[Core:Turns]{turn}.
WeaponFightingStyles.knife: Weapons with this @L[Category:Weapon fighting styles]{fighting style} gain @L[Core:Style Bonus]{SB} when you're @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacking} on your @L[Core:Turns]{turn} while @L[Condition:Hidden]{hidden}.
WeaponFightingStyles.kunai: Weapons with this @L[Category:Weapon fighting styles]{fighting style} gain @L[Core:Style Bonus]{SB} when you're @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacking} if this was sheathed at the start of your @L[Core:Turns]{turn}.
WeaponFightingStyles.phalanx: Weapons with this @L[Category:Weapon fighting styles]{fighting style} gain @L[Core:Style Bonus]{SB} when you're @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacking} a creature if you have an ally using a @L[Category:Shields]{shield} directly between you and your target.
WeaponFightingStyles.quickshot: Weapons with this @L[Category:Weapon fighting styles]{fighting style} gain @L[Core:Style Bonus]{SB} when you're @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacking} on your @L[Core:Turns]{turn} if you had three actions remaining prior to making this @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attack}.
WeaponFightingStyles.savage: Weapons with this @L[Category:Weapon fighting styles]{fighting style} gain @L[Core:Style Bonus]{SB} when you're @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacking} a @L[Condition:Prone]{prone}, @L[Condition:Snared]{snared}, @L[Condition:Frightened]{frightened}, @L[Condition:Suffocating]{suffocating}, or @L[Condition:Immobilized]{immobilized} creature.
WeaponFightingStyles.sniper: Weapons with this @L[Category:Weapon fighting styles]{fighting style} gain @L[Core:Style Bonus]{SB} when you're @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacking} on your @L[Core:Turns]{turn} if you have not @L[Ability:Move]{moved} since the end of your last @L[Core:Turns]{turn} and will have no actions remaining after this @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attack}.
WeaponFightingStyles.swordsman: Weapons with this @L[Category:Weapon fighting styles]{fighting style} gain @L[Core:Style Bonus]{SB} when you're @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacking} for the first time on your @L[Core:Turns]{turn}.
WeaponFightingStyles.trident: Weapons with this @L[Category:Weapon fighting styles]{fighting style} gain @L[Core:Style Bonus]{SB} when you're @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacking} from or into the water.
WeaponFightingStyles.wraparound: Weapons with this @L[Category:Weapon fighting styles]{fighting style} gain @L[Core:Style Bonus]{SB} when you're @L[Category:Attack abilities]{attacking} a creature with a @L[Category:Shields]{shield}.
